title: Why Beef Wellington Is the Smart Move This Holiday Season
sub_head: This showstopper dish is easier to pull off than you think. Prep it a day ahead and just pop it in the oven before the festive meal. Use these pro tips and accessible recipes for turkey, beef and vegan variations.
body:
A CLASSIC Wellington—beef tenderloin smothered in a paté-enhanced mushroom duxelles, baked within a pastry crust—is a dish I’ve always treasured at the table and found elusive in the kitchen. The first time I ventured to make it, I found out why the Wellington is usually reserved for special occasions: Laborious and tricky, the recipe is a minefield of kitchen disasters waiting to happen. If all goes well, expect a juicy, crisp-crusted, richly flavored centerpiece to a festive meal with a tremendous wow factor. If not, you’re left with a soggy log encircling bland, dried-out meat—after a day toiling in the kitchen.
With the approaching holiday in mind, I asked three chefs for their top tips on how to avoid the most common Wellington pitfalls. Their advice and trusty recipes follow.
